instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello team Rossmann and Members,

[U][B]Brief intro:[/B][/U]
My name is Imran Osman
Live in Mombasa Kenya,
Have set up an independent repair and parts Apple shop been 2 years,
I am a self taught Apple repair technician but a Certified Mercedes diagnostic technician so I kinda have a clue on basic repairs.

[U][B]Customer complaint:[/B][/U]
No display on apple mac book pro 13 inch.

[U][B]My findings:[/B][/U]

Device charges well.
Device boots up with chime and fan runs.
No display on LCD.
No visible damage noted on J8300.
No water damage noticed under microscope inspection of board.


[U][B]CARRIED OUT FOLLOWING TEST STEPS[/B][/U]

[U][B]TEST 1: [/B][/U]J8300 pin 1 voltage check= 0.0V
[B][U]RESULT:[/U][/B] I beleive I should get 53v on pin 1 J8300

[U][B]TEST 2:[/B][/U] Checked <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> for short to GND at pin 1 J8300
[U][B]RESULT: [/B][/U]the line is [B]NOT[/B] shorted to GND. Resistance keeps incrementally increasing.

[U][B]TEST 3: [/B][/U] Checked the following caps visually for signs of over heating or damage. <CAPACITOR>C7760</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7761</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7762</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7763</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7764</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7765</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7766</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7767</CAPACITOR>,C7 768,<CAPACITOR>C7769</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7770</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7772</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7773</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7774</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7775</CAPACITOR>,C777 6 AND <CAPACITOR>C7717</CAPACITOR>.
[U][B]RESULT: [/B][/U]None of the caps have signs of heat or water damage. All caps look happy.

[U][B]TEST 4:[/B][/U] Decided to check voltage on above caps.
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] All caps read 0.0v on the positive terminals

[U][B]TEST 5:[/B][/U] Carried out dide test on <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> and checked for voltage on each terminal
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] Diode test was ok <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> passes unidirectionally.
Voltage test = 0.0V

[U][B]TEST 6: [/B][/U]Checked coil L7710 for resistance
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] 0.1 OHM OK

[U][B]TEST 7: [/B][/U]Checked caps <CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR>,<CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR>,AND <CAPACITOR>C7712</CAPACITOR> for short to GND
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] None of the above caps were shorted to GND.


[U][B]TEST 8: [/B][/U]Checked <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> voltage on pins 6,5,2 and 1 at <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] Voltage= 0.0 V
Comment It should be 12.9 v?

[U][B]TEST 9:[/B][/U] Checked voltage at pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT_R</SIGNAL>
[U][B]RESULT:[/B][/U] Voltage of 12.9 V present at pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>



A major problem here in Kenya is availability of parts or for that matter even doner boards.
So I do not have a test LCD neither do I have a board to pick components from unfortunately.

My diagnosis led me to <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> AND <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> simply because I reached a dead end since I could not
comprehend how the backlight circuit actually works and what factors activate the backlight circuit
on <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> and thus <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>.

That said I placed a two weeks order for <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>, replaced both and here I am...........
still no voltages on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and so no amplification and thus no voltage on
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>. :(

[U][B]QUESTION:[/B][/U]
1.How does <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> work and switch ON?
2.Does <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> need to be switched ON by <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>?
3.If question 3 is a yes, then what factors trigger <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> to switch ON <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>

In short I need help.

Thanks and Many Regards from Mombasa Kenya
Imran Osman
IMspot Repairs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
First test should be checking for image with powerfull light on the back of Apple logo from the top cover.
If no image, no reason to look for backlight...

Also check if get 5V at J8300, pins 28-30 atleast few seconds, when you here the chime.
If missing, check voltages at <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>.
At the same time, pin9 should rise to 2.5V; if not, no image/backlight available.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello informaticos,

Thanks for the response.

1. using powerful light on apple logo, no image can be seen on LCD
2. At J8300 pin 28, 29 and 30 all have 5V present
3. pin 9 at J8300 rises to 3.31V

Kindly advise
Regards
Imran

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SOSW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Very likely it is just an LCD problem. Get some cracked test assemblies and make sure that you use the correct year. 2015 machines do not work with 2014 LCD assemblies!
